function-real-valued.tex: A \emph{real-valued function} is a function from a subset of $\reals$ to $\reals.$

limit.tex: Suppose $f$ is a real-valued function from $(a,b)\subseteq\reals$ to $\reals.$ The \emph{limit of $f$ as $x$ approaches $a$} is a real number $L$ such that for every positive real number $\varepsilon$ there is a positive real number $\delta$ such that if $0<|x-a|<\delta$ then $|f(x)-L|<\varepsilon.$ It is said that $f$ approaches $L$ as $x$ approaches $a$ and is written $f(x)\to L$ as $x\to a$ or $\lim_{x\to a}f(x)=L.$ Symbolically, $\lim_{x\to a} f(x)=L$ if and only if $$(\forall \varepsilon > 0 ) (\exists \delta > 0) (\forall x \in (a, b)) (0 < |x - p| < \delta \implies |f(x) - L| < \varepsilon).$$

continuity.tex: Suppose $f(x)$ is a real-valued function. Then $f(x)$ is \emph{continuous} at $x=c$ if and only if: \begin{enumerate} \item $f(c)$ is defined \item $\lim\limits_{x \to c} f(x)$ exists \item $\lim\limits_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c)$ \end{enumerate}

squeeze-theorem.tex: (Squeeze Theorem). Suppose $f,$ $g,$ and $h$ are real-valued functions such that $$f(x) \leq g(x) \leq h(x)$$ for all real $x.$ If $\lim_{x\to c} f(x) = L = \lim_{x\to c} h(x),$ then $$\lim\limits_{x\to c}g(x) = L$$ (because $g$ is squeezed between $f$ and $h$ at $c$).
